data.title: Smackdown: Life on Mars vs. Eleventh Hour
data.meta_description: Science-y crime dramas Life on Mars and Eleventh Hour are duking it out to dominate TV’s plum 10 p.m. Thursday time slot. The shows have a lot in common: Both are based on U.K. miniseries; both feature a crime fighter aided by a beautiful blonde colleague; both premiered Oct. 9. But that’s where things diverge. […]
data.text:
Science-y crime dramas Life on Mars and Eleventh Hour are duking it out to dominate TV's plum 10 p.m. Thursday time slot. The shows have a lot in common: Both are based on U.K. miniseries; both feature a crime fighter aided by a beautiful blonde colleague; both premiered Oct. 9.

But that's where things diverge. In ABC's Life on Mars, a time-traveling cop (Irish actor Jason O'Mara, pictured above left) catches bad guys with help from Gretchen Mol (The Notorious Bettie Page). CBS' Eleventh Hour teams a brainy biophysicist (British actor Rufus Sewell, pictured above right) with Marley Shelton (Death Proof) as high-tech sleuths.

Does science trample time travel in this prime-time face-off? We've put together a five-round, voting-enabled smackdown to get your take on which show is breaking new ground.

Click on the head next to the best argument in each round.

ABC's Life on Mars and CBS' Eleventh Hour air Thursdays at 10 p.m.

Photos courtesy ABC, CBS

You can call politicians castigating the childless and companies marketing AI assistants a lot of things, but it's au courant to call them weird. The Era of Weird has been a long time coming—but may have a cringey future ahead.
